utterance: SB: Thank you Jose. This is great. Okay, cool. So, anybody wants to go first? Can we start with what sort of knowledge gaps exist in terms of science and then the need for theory and experiment to more better address each other's needs as it pertains to NES.

annotations.encourage particpation: SB is encouraging the group to participate by asking who wants to go first.
annotations.propose decision: SB proposes to start the discussion by focusing on knowledge gaps in science and the interplay between theory and experiment in addressing those gaps as they pertain to NES.

utterance: FJ: Sure, I can I can just make a few comments that everyone can add to it. So, our group mostly on catalyst development. So we actually have collaborators working on the theory side. Leo actually is one of our collaborators. We actually published a paper together last year. So, one of the challenges we see in our experimental side is trying to understand the reaction intermediates, trying to figure out the reaction mechanism. Some of the tools we frequently use trying to probe the reactive intermediates, but we have the trouble because the reactive intermediates usually have very short lifetime. And they are not really have high coverage on the surface of the catalyst. So that's make even infrared or Raman become extremely difficult to to see those intermediates. I think theory have much better chance to readily telling us what's going on the surface. And also, I think on the other side, I heard there are a few groups actually here also working on developing new tools to understand the electrochemical interface. I think it's definitely there's a need for us who work on the catalyst and also collaborate closely with people working on computational modeling and ab initio calculations. So, that's my two cents, okay.

annotations.present new idea: FJ introduces the challenge of understanding reaction intermediates and mechanisms in catalyst development, highlighting the need for collaboration between experimentalists and theorists.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: FJ supports the need for collaboration by mentioning their experience working with theorists and publishing a paper together.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: FJ explains the challenges in probing reactive intermediates due to their short lifetime and low coverage on the catalyst surface, making techniques like infrared or Raman spectroscopy difficult.
annotations.propose decision: FJ proposes the need for closer collaboration between catalyst developers and computational modelers/ab initio calculators.

utterance: LS: Very good. So, really interesting points that intermediates in electro catalytic CO2 reduction are really difficult to see because coverage is low, they don't hang out for too long. utterance: LS: Sorry, I can jump in. I definitely agree with that perspective that the spectroscopy experimentally is very tough. So we're also struggling with vibrational techniques. So turning to some x-ray absorption and emission spectroscopy to try to look at intermediates. I think some things that could be useful from a computational perspective to maybe complement these types of techniques is first even just modeling and predicting complex spectroscopies based on the molecular orbital geometry of the reactants, intermediates, and product species that we're expecting to see. I think also the hard part about this is really just bridging the gap between idealized models and then really messy systems. And so that really comes down to what Fang was also saying about signal to noise. So other things I was thinking about was techniques like modulation excitation spectroscopy that we can use for experiment, but that actually do they would be significantly enhanced if there's appropriate sort of theory or data processing to supplement that. And I think it's having expertise from a theoretical perspective would help an experimental group like mine really make the most of these approaches.

annotations.express agreement: The speaker starts by agreeing with the previous speaker's statement about the difficulty of spectroscopy experiments.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports their agreement by mentioning their own struggles with vibrational techniques and their subsequent shift to x-ray spectroscopy.
annotations.present new idea: The speaker proposes modulation excitation spectroscopy as another experimental technique that could benefit from theoretical support and data processing.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker reiterates the importance of theoretical expertise for maximizing the potential of experimental approaches.

utterance: RG: I can jump in a little bit. I think one thing from the theory side especially, and this kind of goes back to what Lindsey hinted at, is just the complexity of the experimental environments. And it's hard for us to look for something unless we know what we're looking for. So a lot of times from the purely experimental papers, you have no idea what the real atomic type structure is. And I can't build a model unless I can at least get some reasonable guesses of atomic structures to start from and test whether they're reasonable and things like that. So just kind of bridging that communication gap, I think is a big challenge that I think a lot of the spectroscopy type stuff you're mentioning can definitely help with, but is definitely difficult.

utterance: FJ: Sorry about this. Yes, I also want to follow up on this. So I fully agree that the complexity in experiments is challenging for theorists. From computational side, it's generally difficult to achieve good balance between the accuracy and the efficiency. Sometimes we have to sacrifice the accuracy for efficiency so we can start for example, we can start studying large system, we can start studying materials. But sometimes it's very important to consider those complex factors although they may cause significant computational cost. For example, in I'm more familiar with electrocatalysis and only the liquid interface. So usually people often neglect for example, the surface charge and also neglect the solvation explicitly solvation. And this approach, this conventional approach is simplified, but it's very successful in studying many different electrocatalysts because the computational cost is relatively low. However, there are also many experiments that cannot be explained using such simplified approach. And for those materials, we really need to consider the for example, the surface charge, the explicit water solvation effect. And without those consideration, we cannot explain the experiments. So I think there is a strong need to develop and apply more advanced computational measure to better understand the experiments.

utterance: SB: Any prospects for accelerating the cycle? Yeah, I could This would be a good spot for me to jump in. One of the things naturally about most electrochemical interfaces is they're horrible and they're complicated. And like many of the theorists have pointed out, they need to have a really good idea of at least a starting point what the actual type of site that's dominating the chemistry or the reactivity of the system is, which we often don't know from the start. That's actually a really appealing aspect of using microscopic approaches to actually mapping reactivity. So if you actually go down and locally measure where catalysis is actually efficient within these kind of microscopic material systems, you can kind of jump in a little quicker on that kind of feedback loop that we like to always envision works well where you have an experimental observation and then we theoretically predict or rationalize it and predict better structures, right? I mean, if we go down and identify already, you know, where the actual reaction is happening, you can structurally characterize that and you can use that as a jumping off point for future studies.
